title: Inline StepRecorder/ErrorRecorder into AgentLoop
description:
## Scope

Remove `StepRecorder` and `ErrorRecorder` classes. Inline their logic as private methods on `AgentLoop`. Delete `ErrorRecordingResult` data class. AgentLoop directly builds `StepExecution`, emits events, and records steps.

This removes two indirection layers that add no value — their logic is ~30 lines each and only called from AgentLoop.

## Files to change

Delete:
- `packages/agents/src/Core/Lifecycle/StepRecorder.php` — DELETE
- `packages/agents/src/Core/Lifecycle/ErrorRecorder.php` — DELETE
- `packages/agents/src/Core/Lifecycle/ErrorRecordingResult.php` — DELETE (if exists; otherwise inline result is local vars)

Modify:
- `packages/agents/src/Core/AgentLoop.php`:
  - Remove `StepRecorder` and `ErrorRecorder` from constructor/fields
  - Add private `recordStep(AgentState): AgentState` — builds StepExecution, emits continuationEvaluated + stateUpdated, records in state
  - Add private `recordError(Throwable, AgentState): AgentState` — delegates to errorHandler, builds failure step, emits events, records in state
  - Update `handleStopException()` to use the new `recordStep()` directly
  - Update `onError()` to use the new `recordError()` directly
  - Step number derived as `$state->stepCount() + 1` (not read from transient field)
  - Step startedAt read from `$state->execution()->currentStepStartedAt()`

## Acceptance criteria

- `StepRecorder`, `ErrorRecorder`, `ErrorRecordingResult` files deleted
- AgentLoop no longer instantiates or references these classes
- Step recording logic lives as `AgentLoop::recordStep()` private method
- Error recording logic lives as `AgentLoop::recordError()` private method
- Event emission order and payloads identical to before:
  - `continuationEvaluated` emitted with stepNumber, stopSignal, stopReason
  - `stateUpdated` emitted after step recorded in state
  - `executionFailed` emitted on fatal error (error path only)
- `stepCompleted` event still emitted after recording in iterate() loop

## Validations / checks / tests

- Run full agent test suite: `vendor/bin/pest packages/agents/tests/`
- Event payload regression: capture events via wiretap in a test, verify:
  - `continuationEvaluated` contains correct `stepNumber`, `stopSignal`
  - `stateUpdated` fires after step recorded
  - `executionFailed` fires on error with correct exception
  - Step numbering is sequential (1, 2, 3...)
- Error path: verify AgentErrorHandler is still called, stop signal propagated, failure step recorded
- Stop exception path: verify `handleStopException` records step with signal from exception
- No references to `StepRecorder`, `ErrorRecorder`, `ErrorRecordingResult` remain (grep)

title: [enhancement] AgentFinished event should reflect termination reason in status
description:
## Problem

When an agent is forcibly stopped by a guard criterion (e.g., TokenUsageLimit), the AgentFinished event reports `status: 'in_progress'` which is confusing since the agent has actually finished.

## Evidence

Log output:
```
AgentFinished • status => 'in_progress' • steps => 1
```

This occurs because:
1. TokenUsageLimit stopped continuation after step 1
2. AgentState.status was never transitioned from 'in_progress'
3. AgentFinished event just reflects the state's status field

## Expected Behavior

When an agent terminates due to a guard criterion, the status should indicate the termination was abnormal, e.g.:
- `status: 'interrupted'` or `status: 'stopped'`
- Or add a separate `stopReason` field alongside status

## Current Behavior

Status remains 'in_progress' even after forced termination, making it hard to distinguish between:
- Agent that completed naturally
- Agent interrupted by token limit
- Agent interrupted by time limit
- Agent interrupted by step limit

## Suggested Fix

Option A: Add `terminationReason` field to AgentFinished event (non-breaking)
Option B: Update AgentState.status to 'interrupted' when guards force stop
Option C: Add `wasInterrupted` boolean to AgentFinished event

## Impact

Low - debugging/observability improvement only
close_reason: Fixed: AgentFinished now sets status to Completed/Failed based on StopReason

## Scope

Change `CanUseTools::useTools()` to return `AgentState` instead of `AgentStep`. Move `Tools` and `CanExecuteToolCalls` from per-call parameters to driver constructors. Inject `HookStackObserver` into drivers so they can merge hook-mutated state. Delete `CanReportObserverState` interface and all implementations. Simplify `AgentLoop::useTools()` to a single driver call.

This is the foundational change — it makes state flow explicit and removes the hidden observer-state side-channel that makes the current code hard to reason about.

## Files to change

Contracts:
- `packages/agents/src/Core/Contracts/CanUseTools.php` — change return type to `AgentState`, remove `Tools` and `CanExecuteToolCalls` params
- `packages/agents/src/Core/Contracts/CanReportObserverState.php` — DELETE

Drivers:
- `packages/agents/src/Drivers/ToolCalling/ToolCallingDriver.php` — accept `Tools`, `CanExecuteToolCalls`, `?HookStackObserver` via constructor; return `AgentState`; remove `CanReportObserverState` impl; merge observer state before returning
- `packages/agents/src/Drivers/ReAct/ReActDriver.php` — same pattern
- `packages/agents/src/Drivers/Testing/DeterministicAgentDriver.php` — accept `Tools`, `CanExecuteToolCalls` via constructor; return `AgentState`

- `packages/agents/src/AgentBuilder/AgentBuilder.php` — `buildDriver()` now injects `Tools`, `CanExecuteToolCalls`, and `HookStackObserver` into driver constructors. Construction order: eventEmitter → observer → toolExecutor → driver (reversed from current: driver → observer → toolExecutor)

## Acceptance criteria

- `CanUseTools::useTools(AgentState $state): AgentState` — single param, returns state with step embedded
- Drivers receive `Tools`, `CanExecuteToolCalls`, and (optionally) `HookStackObserver` via constructor
- Each driver merges observer state internally before returning `AgentState`
- `AgentLoop::useTools()` is a single call to `$this->driver->useTools($state)` — no post-processing
- `CanReportObserverState` interface deleted, no references remain
- `AgentLoop::applyObserverState()` deleted
- `ToolExecutor` no longer implements `CanReportObserverState`
